chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should aim to make presidential elections feel equally meaningful to voters everywhere while keeping the states’ role as the units that run and certify elections. A workable compromise is to keep the Electoral College but replace winner-take-all with a uniform proportional method (with a small threshold to avoid splintering), and pair it with clear national rules for ballot access, audits, and automatic recounts in very close contests. If the public later prefers a true national popular vote, the National Popular Vote compact can serve as a reversible pilot once those integrity standards are in place.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Electoral College reform should keep a meaningful state role while making outcomes track the voters more closely so fewer people feel written off in “safe” states. A practical bridge is to end winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (optionally with ranked-choice ballots to ensure majority support), and to pair that with clear, uniform national standards for ballot access, counting, audits, and timely recounts. States that prefer a national result could also join the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact once safeguards and certification rules are clearly in place.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A balanced reform should keep the states’ role in running elections while making the outcome track the voters more closely so people in every community—rural and urban, working families and retirees—feel their ballot matters. A practical path is to reduce winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (or by district with strong anti-gerrymandering safeguards) and set clear, uniform national standards for ballot access, counting, audits, and recount timelines. If broader agreement emerges, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact could be an additional step toward one person, one vote while preserving stable, transparent administration and trust in close results.
